EE9iqREe0LMtL23AlHKxuw.text: I had the most fantastic and huge all day Spanish breakfast here last weekend. It would have made perfect hangover food. Two fried eggs, spanish chorizo style sausage, lightly fried potatoes, bacon and toast. The service was a little slow, but the waitress apologised so much afterwards and the food was definitely worth the wait. This would be a great place to hang out for a lazy brunch. There's lot of space and because it's away from the main King's Cross drag & off the beaten track from tourists, I imagine it would be reasonably easy to get a seat at weekends.

gObtZA_HmWovGiyOLSShjA.text: I had a really good lunch here recently:ontolondon.blogspot.com/…  I really enjoyed everything I ate and especially loved their fabada. Camino is a massive space and I was impressed with the look and feel. A bit too kitsch for my taste (if you can believe that) but cool enough not to insult anyone's tastes.

myAKj6Re6XhGQt0JrBgY3w.text: "Camino" ... this word sounds like the Hindi word meaning rascals ... :) ... so i had a chuckle when i first heard where we would be going for the Spanish dinner ... the third stop in our world tour.The place is very large and well decorated ... with a long bar. But they didn't have a table big enough for the 12 of us and so we had to split into two groups.The table i was in decided to order just alcohol and tapas ... many of them. So we tried a blend of very different food items interspaced with gulps of some great sangria. I especially liked the potato, the small sausages and the prawn. Since i had come late, i ordered late ... and my order was the most weird looking dish that i could find in my short perusal of the menu. So the last item to arrive on the table was black rice with cuttlefish and squid ink (no idea what that is). But it tasted really good. The cuttlefish looked like mussels (or were they mussels ... don't know for sure :p). We rounded up the meal with dessert, with me having 3 scoops of some delicious vanilla. At £18 / head excluding the drinks, it is a very reasonable place to go to in an area pretty much devoid of good eateries.

XtDmquo33KOBeOOFRLQ2eg.text: Having only sampled the bar area of Camino, I can't speak for the restaurant - but after reading favourable reviews I have to say I was a trifle disappointed with the drinks-and-tapas portion of the gastronomic venture. Well located in King's Cross this is a popular spot for the office workers of the locality who are after post-work drinking without a bus fare to Islington; it serves the purpose tolerably well with lots of space and an appealing vibe. The £15 house rosé we sampled was a bit below par (even house wines should be tasty) and although the décor is lively and fun it does feel pretty chain-y and not exclusive enough to justify the prices in the next-door restaurant. Staff were tolerably helpful and there's a buzzy atmosphere. Camino's convenient but not highly commended by me.

njUpSKdMAQzCxKQENE1JjQ.text: great as always! I have been to this place a couple of times, the first time just for wine and cheese and last night for a birthday dinner. On both occasions the place was lilely but not too crowded. We had all the mixed platters plus some cheese and fried squid and everything was great - I recommend the fried squid and the padron peppers, just like in spain!We drank red wine, very good value priced at £14. I ended my meal with a cafe bonbon (espresso and condensed milk) beautiful!

gawLTsck68BjjCl0PKLSSQ.text: After winning bar of year in the Observer Food Monthly (you never know the journo's may get a few free drinks thrown their way seeing as their new office is practically next door!) and living incredibly close I decided to check this place out. Ok, the food is very good, and not too pricey for the quality, there is also a good choice of Spanish wines that won't break the bank and I can have absolutey no complaints over the service. The décor is well done, a little rustic, a little Spanish and not too cheesy. This is certainly a good place to go for a nice meal. What it definitely isn't is a place to go for a few (cheap) beers. They don't serve pints; it's either a jug or a glass of beer (in a nice frosted glass). The glass (which must be about a half pint) is the price of a pint in most places, so the equivalent of a pint will cost well over £5. Some people might be fine with this, but not me.

MbKBMDMHilSTcvLjQNYv5g.text: Hidden in what seems to be a cave/dungeon, Camino boasts some delicious sangria, and a clean,  very large restaurant and bar.  While the bar is filled with the after work crowd my friends and I went here on a Friday night for late night drinks and were very pleased.  Drinks were well priced in the 4 to 7 pounds range and there was plenty of space for our group of 12 to sit and talk which is usually hard to find on a Friday night.  The tapas looked very appetizing, and I hope to go back for them!!

lOJpx_oIGtSoHv_BbqfBSA.text: Sat at the bar before a gig at Scala with a generous portion of lomo and a chilled glass of sherry. Lovely. Avoid the post work crowd.

RFxiektTbriPSK-wVGBsHw.text: Set in the courtyard behind King's Cross Starbucks and McDonalds, Camino is pretentiously high-class. It's impossible to get a table without booking, although the restaurant is rarely full. However, they turn away customers who show up even on nights when business is quiet and there is plenty of space, if they have not pre-booked. Despite the poor customer service, the food is of excellent quality. The menu itself is of classy graphic design, a line representing a journey through spain. I had a cravat of very light, fruity white wine, squid-ink rice, and something intensely chocolatey, melted, molten, fudgey, for dessert. Delicious. Almost justifies the pricey-ness.

DOum5PQbpwjcYCBn-3GusQ.text: This is one of my trusty brunch spots when I travel for work -- my London office is right nearby, and this is one of the only decent spots in the area that's open before noon on Sunday.  The omelettes are quite good, and it's a reliable choice for dinner as well.  Don't miss the sangria!

4uE5a4BMnab-3b2Ca0WRcQ.text: Decent breakfast venue with free wifi and plenty of room if you need to chat quietly about top secret plans. Even if you don't, you can enjoy either bacon or spanish sausage with eggs for a reasonable price of 3.50 GBP. I've just realised that I made a huge mistake in putting the tea bag in the cup for the tea, rather than the mini teapot, hence I probably would have got twice as many brews in this morning as I did. Having said that, 6 cups of tea with breakfast is extreme even for me...

scF3aDK-hFgceD3hBigE8g.text: wanted churros so i researched till i came across camino, called them up asking if they are severing chrros, women in phone said yes, got there now and another member of staff said we stop serving due it not being breakfast no more, but they agreed to serve me them, when i got it, it wasn't all that, no sugar coating, just some small churros on a plate with a chocolate glass for the dip, the dip was not nice, didn't go together with churros as it was not sweet, and they serve me drinks with this, and i paid £10 for like nothing, a bar of cadbury dairy milk would of been better, waste of time.

9f_muo3q4NgtcvwsdyucbQ.text: nice mexican place in soho. tip go the bar downstairs...super hip/trendy lounge. they make great margaritas.

x4jR9qypL76GFMsrpanOMQ.text: King's Cross isn't exactly a culinary destination, but I was in the hood meeting friends who live nearby and we needed a spot that was still serving dinner after 930pm... and so, Camino.  I was pleasantly surprised.  First, I don't love Spanish food and this was pretty solid.  I give top bread marks to the country loaf which we ordered with garlic mayonnaise (did you know spanish for aioli is "alioli"?) and the sauteed monkfish and chargrilled pork skewers were excellent.  Less amazing were the fried calamari (better when smothered in alioli) and tough slices of chorizo.  I was most disappointed with the "jamon iberico" -  this is meant to be the best spanish ham but strangely, I found it lacking in flavour.We only had tapas, but they also serve large mains... as well as an extensive breakfast/brunch selection.The restaurant is large with exposed brick, and the large bar separates the main dining area from the bar area.  The bar was buzzing when we were there (thurs night) - crowded and good music.  Opening hours are a bit confusing so I have pasted them in full below:Juice BarMonday to Friday 8am - 4pm(Breakfast served 8 - 11.30pm)Saturday 9am- 4pm(Breakfast served 9am - 3pm)Sunday 11am - 4pm(Breakfast served 11am - 4pm)BarMonday to Wednesday midday - midnightThursday to Saturday midday - 1am(Tapas served midday - 11pm)Sunday 11am - 11pm(Tapas served midday - 10pm)RestaurantMonday to Friday 12 - 3pm, 6.30 - 11pmSaturday 7- 11pmSunday closed(A la carte and tapas menu, minimum food spend £12pp. Express menu available every Monday to Friday lunchtime + Monday and Tuesday evening if seated by 6.30pm)

gsbER2HiyEQxMbvn-5DT4Q.text: Love the atmosphere here. The staff are friendly and it's always packed. There's a nice decor - all rustic wood and leather sofas. I would say it's quite pricey though. But their brunch is amazing!

6WqQMVzxPh8vN0NJmwQTYA.text: Since I live in a residence hall near the area, I always come here after noon until right before supper time to do my reading. It's always wise to open up a tab as you arrive if you're planning to stick around - and why wouldn't you? The ambience will not disappoint - relaxed yet classy. The food caters to most tastebuds - a selection of tapas that they start serving at 4pm and pastries for bfast. An impressive wine selection. Wireless internet. Approachable staff. At night, this place feels like one of those hidden gems. Truly recommended.

jr4qX8smf-b6p1IKPz26HQ.text: Camino serves up a good selection of tasty dishes, in a light and airy restaurant. The bar is a good hangout too and serves a reasonable variety of decent wines. Overall, prices are reasonable. With large bookings, they'll ask you to pay a per person deposit which almost put me off booking but I can understand their need to protect against losing out if a large booking fails to turn up.

-AZca4Lw2fzE9Mlx0tjL9g.text: Great location and good tapas! Recommend this hidden gem!

XbwIX9RImr6NNiHI4GiDdg.text: We were being dragged out of the comfort of bed, hang overs in tow for a friend's birthday drinks. What's more, not only but also we had to get to King's Cross. And it was raining. King's Cross has been an absolute dive fo years with only a few things to keep you there of an evening if really pushed. But what with all the 'regeneration' and the truck loads of cash that have been poured into the area, there are a few things emerging from the rubble. There's King's Place, a new cultural centre and of course the requisite Starbucks amongst other things. But hidden away from the straying eyes of the general mish mash of people is Caminos. And Cominos is brilliant!! I'm hoping the ever so slightly naff crowd was due to the Festive season... but even so, we had a great time and stayed til we were asked to leave. Within moments you forget you're in King's Cross, forget you are in London and instead fall into the heart warming sense that you are in the middle of Barcelona. The tapas is great.... plentiful and moreish. The spanish beer is on tap, the house wine is super dry and super tasty and the staff are all Spanish. And not too mean on the eye neither. Oh... and the very very best bit is the table football!!! uh huh, you heard me right. Get your behinds down there.

HX2e3QWRwn2OA_TADeVCMg.text: I have eaten and drunk here at various time of the day since it opened, having sampled the tapas, eaten in the main restaurant and drunk in the bar a number of times. It is a wonderful oasis in the busy KX area. Really you don't think you are in the area at all! However, my favourite time to go there is breakfast, when it is generally quiet and you can grab a lovely breakfast - pan fried eggs and bacon/spanish sausage a personal favourite. Try the freshly squeezed orange and coffee selection as well.

iTOZ6o8bTGUFLCLoqmfMFw.text: The place tries hard to be a quality Spanish cafe and succeeds in most areas  the food is great and catches the traditional taste from the classical recipes. Also, the staff is nice and polite and you can rely to have a good time at Camino.

n7Bv-65larZhHkiLMazdEw.text: This place is a bitch to find. It confounded my GPS, not that that would be hard, piece of crap that it is, and had me walking up and down Kings Cross, just like the old days, eh boys? Camino has the sorry fate of looking exactly like a gastro-pub. Sitting here, you are not going to be fooled into thinking you are in the Costa Del Sol. But who wants to be in a grotty package holiday hellhole anyway, if Kings Cross isn't the perfect location for tapas and sangria, then I don't know where is. Camino  has a restaurant and a bar area, where if you are looking to chat up a city twat or two over a glass of wine, you are in the right place. Like I said, the restaurant ambience is unremarkable, except for the huge domed ceiling... it was totally a gastro-pub in earlier days. Huge menu with loads of authentic sounding tapas dishes, fish and meats. We ordered a variety of tapas to share, meh.. they were okay, nothing blew me away. I felt the vegetarian platter could have been more adventurous and the meat platter seemed low on actual meat and used chillis as a big filler portion. Carnivores will not get their kicks off ordering this, believe me, I could have eaten it and I'm a vegetarian. The dessert was good, almond tart with warmed cream. Their sangria is gooood. Would I go back? Yes but only if I ordered my own main course.

hlCBx2dLEyFa6ub7NLxp6w.text: i came here for some tapas last night after seeing david nicholls at king's place.  the menu is pretty big and has a lot of variety.  for 2 of us, we got the mixto platter, the gambas, and the alegrias peppers.  the peppers were spicy and came w/ some toasts.  the gambas were nice and garlicky and the best dish by far.  the mixed platter came w/ ham fritters, cheese fritters, chorizo (2 small pieces), fried calamari, and some potatoes.  i thought it was a rip-off for 17.50 GBP for what you get, especially when most of it was just batter.  i couldn't even tell which of the fritters had ham in them and which ones were just cheese, b/c both of them just tasted like cheese to me.

g8s_bDCxdyc98IK8jE3ODA.text: This place is about as Spanish as Trafalgar Square.  Not bad, but not Spanish.  I didn't eat here but if the food is as Spanish as the draught beers, one Dutch, one Portugese, then it will be as authentic as a $10 Rolex.  But enough of the Iberophilic stuff, it's a big modern bar with a big modern customer base.  Nothing offensive, nothing particularly appealing, it could be an All Bar One.

W_SX-LffTB3tk1xftemewQ.text: My favourite bar in North London.Celebrated my birthday there and had drinks and tapas in Pepito across the courtyard too.Food is great, atmosphere is electric and transport links are second to none.It's like Spain, but without the weather!

b_Z7-ik20H5KR5cPLYn21A.text: Hygiene. That's what Camino is. It's in one of the fairly-recently-done-up parts of Kings Cross and is full of office types eating olives with some mildly overpriced and unsurprisingly average wine each evening. However it is nicely set back from the hustle and bustle of its surrounding areas, and the tapas is acceptable for the London.

HO4Hd1BlXJxavMh_AbiO9w.text: I dare you, DARE you, to find another DJ who accompanies the music he's spinning by busting a live jazz flute solo. Yes, the DJ was playing A FLUTE behind his decks into a microphone. A FLUTE.The music in the bar area was unbearably loud, but that flute playing maverick just made it at least entertaining.Don't expect to have a quiet, civilised, after-work chat in this bar - it is constantly rammed with people yelling rather than talking. Still, we managed to find three stools and perched ourselves at one of the high-top tables for a bottle of Spanish white wine (surprisingly decent) and some tapas.We all shared the vegetariano platter, along with some gambas al ajillo and an order of "olla gitana" -- a glorious ceramic pot with enough butternut squash and chickpea stew for two. The flavours in that last dash were outstanding (after the initial wait to avoid burning off our tongues -- it came to us absolutely boiling). A strong taste of smoked paprika adds to the subtlety of the ingredients. Loved it.If the food wasn't so nice, I'd hate this place. Not comfortable, too noisy, etc etc. But I seriously enjoyed my brief evening here last night. Can't wait for the next jazz flute sesh.

9p-sCQ9PvbhMGMROFP3rhA.text: Had a great evening here last Sunday watching the Brazil Ivory Coast game. Lively atmosphere as you would expect with a number of TVs dotted around the large bar areas with the main screen in the lovely courtyard. Post match entertainment from a Latin flavoured combo kept the party vibe going until closing time. Despite the crowds food was delivered quickly, reasonably priced and very tasty. I'd recommend in particular the black pig and the Sarten De Patatas - sublime. Great addition to the Kings Cross area and I'm looking forward tocoming back to sample the delights of the sister bar Pepito. 9/10 Laid back atomosphere with reasonably priced food and drink.

zpnTqWnuo5c2f2Bqe_TSkg.text: Had a drink in the courtyard here tonight.good service, and good atmosphere in a decent outside space which was away from the road. The inside looked good too with the food looking like it would be worth a try next time

-3RKZxvYOtqeQfDO1SO2uw.text: Spain is my secret passion and this place is coming close to delivering the true Espanol experience in Central London. Not the same though. It is never the same unfortunately. The food tastes ok and the location is quite good for reflective thoughts.

9cCW86Oo9NiYipKWE8muxA.text: The food here is fantastic. Can't speak for the events as I've never been, but the tapas are spectacular.

KIS9ctdXReb8SbIV-oufXw.text: When the powers that be decided to plumb Kings Cross into the Eurostar network, they faced a problem. If first impressions are so important, how do you get around the fact that starting off a London sojourn in Kings Cross is like starting off a relationship by sniffing someone's backside? What happened, I hear you ask. Well, they did what most governments do... they encouraged people to throw lots of money at it. The result is still the Kings Cross we know and loathe, with places like Camino tacked on or hidden away inside it. At face value, Camino doesn't seem so bad. It's large, clean, sports exposed brickwork and plenty of faux-Spanish paraphernalia. What it lacks, sadly, is personality or accomplishment. I tend to avoid Spanish wine, so asking the staff for a little advice off the exclusively Iberian wine list seemed in order. No one knew what I was talking about or how to help. In the end, we had a beer. I didn't try the food, so I can't really comment. Perhaps it's wonderful. Perhaps it's not. There's nothing really wrong with Camino. It just lacks character, charm or competence, but there's nothing unusual about that in London - or indeed any other big city. It's just sort of there, possibly the only clean aspirer to bar status in the area, which will make it plenty of people's choice by default. That's ok. If you're in the area, I suppose it's probably as good as you're going to get.

5YL6_533G4FhKh09cu5RnQ.text: There can be only one word to describe the food at Camino: AMAZEBALLS. Fo' sho. Stumbled into Camino on Friday night near closing and the place was crazy crowded. Despite the throngs of people and the resulting crowd noise (a little bit excessive, perhaps, but the food was worth it), our service was excellent: attentive, friendly, and best of all, blazingly fast. Everything we ordered was excellent and rivaled the quality that I've had in Spain. Out of everything we ordered, most notable were the Gambas Al Ajillo (shrimp that arrives bubbly and simmering in wine, garlic, and other spices), and the Presa Iberica, which is roast pork served medium rare. I'll admit, eating undercooked pork made me nervous, having grown up with stories about trichinosis and whatnot, but OMG. You have to try this. It'll blow your mind.  Also, I love the wine list. The Rioja I ended up choosing was the among the best I've ever had. If I were in London longer, I'd be eating here once a week.

zwxbd5kOCv5e-xeioZ21JQ.text: Camino is an everyday kind of place which won't break the bank. It's easily the best bar in the King's Cross area (not hard I know) and its location in the Regent Quarter development will take you far away from the grimy streets of the Cross. The food is above par too - you can either order tapas at the bar or dine in the restaurant where they serve an excellent value set lunch (£15 for 3 courses). But what I really like about this place is its cracking selection of affordable Spanish wine (especially the red). Oh and they have 'proper' table footy where you can re-enact Barcelona v Real Madrid.

HFTAVeV8kMU6JpyUDaahDg.text: Lively Spanish bar/restaurant hidden just away from Cruz del Rey. It's popular and the yard it is sequestered in is certainly a nice location, lots of space outside for smokers or for claustrophobics but it's just not my cup of tea. The choice of beers is very limited and the one's that are there are not so good. Resorted to buying cider in a bottle but that led to an unexpected visit to the cashpoint later in the evening, so expensive was that round! I didn't try the food so I cannot comment on that I guess I can see why some people could like this bar and at least its not part of a soulless chain, but I'd be very surprised to find myself

68Va4fA0lUGMpMl4kPnkuA.text: I was there a couple of weeks ago for a girls night out for dinner. The location is really nice, the place is well decorated and the food is good for the price. However, I did not find it fantastic. I have had much better tapas before. Don't get me wrong though, although I was not overly impressed with the place, the service was good, staff was friendly and for what we ate, it was definitely good value for money. A visit to the loo is definitely needed - must-see deco! Would I go there again? Probably not but I guess if I go to a Tapas restaurant, I need to feel that lively spanish atmosphere. It was not quite there for me.

L-ILDZyLNzx03vUkA7LXBw.text: Camino is a surprisingly nice place to go out, considering the King's Cross location. You can't see the restaurant from Pentonville road as it is tucked away in the inner yard. So it is easy to end up thinking that there is no nice  place to go out in that area, which by the way, would be quite true.After work the place is packed with men in suits but don't let this fool you as it still manages to remain its Latin influenced relaxed atmosphere. So works especially during the summers when  you can hang around outside. I think the place is best  to go just for a drink, or maybe for a laid back meal. I have tried out some Tapas that was all right and always nice to share with your friends.The picture is from:http://www.camino.uk.com

photos.caption: Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom

kS3FN1cW4O_f6sbCV8RIiQ.text: Lunchtime with a friend experience - being in King's cross it makes an excellent meeting place at a decent quality venue. Enjoyed the "Spanish" food and wine in a classy looking place tucked behind the hectic streets next to the station. This restaurant may not have fared well as a Spanish food place, but there is little alternative given the location and convenience.

YW2lRDCQtEcjW5mY780BqQ.text: We went to this restaurant as it is close to my husband's work. The service was excellent, as was the food which all arrived in good time as we had to make it to a show. Really excellent baby octopus, brilliant spicy sauce on the potatoes and pimientos de padron as good as you would expect in any tapas bar in Spain. Will definitely be going back!

z6N0krYpCoPBlOvHR6Jjtw.text: Cominos is hidden behing rather grotty pentiville road in kings cross just next to starbucks you will find a little passage down to a sweet coblled yard and here is a nice spanish bar and resturant cominos.The wine and cocktails are really good, there is a nice atmosphere and the tapas is very tasty.The place is quite big and there are lots of little rooms and a great outside space so its really good for groups. There is eating, dancing, drinking...what else could you wish for. A good find in a lacking area of kings cross.

c-OHYzB7TGy1IEE1j8QpFw.text: We came here for a friend's leaving do as it's a bar/restaurant so it was a perfect environment to get all close friends for dinner and then the rest to join us at the bar for drinks!I didn't know this place exists unless it's been recommended or you work/live around the area. It was tucked into a new build so it's not that noticeable on the high street.On arrival on a Sat night, it was very quiet & empty. But I trust my friend that she wouldn't choose a dead restaurant. As the night went on, it got a bit busier. Pretty happy that we weren't the only diners. However the bar seems to be more busy than the restaurant.Our waiter was very attentive, or maybe a bit too much. Although I can't complain much as he was very friendly and tried to make some jokes. I've had Spanish food at various restaurants and this restaurant seems to be ok. As there were a number of us, we had to go for the set menu. A reasonable price for a good variety of choices. Some dishes are better than others but one thing we all agreed on was the dessert. It was a mixture of a variety of cakes/ice cream etc and some melted and none of them taste good. I had a look at their menu recently and I don't think they are serving the same deserts as what we had. I would recommend people to go to Camino but you don't need to sweat yourself to rush to have a meal there. There are other plenty of great Spanish restaurant!

btwduj7rg9tcwmA8kJUZ1A.text: Visiting with friends I found Camino's a great location to enjoy some nice food, good drinks, great location, and amazing company. With friendly service and very tasty delights this is a great place for those of you passing through Kings Cross and finding yourself a bit peckish. Many will walk past this location having never known it was around, but I recommend you stop by and take a look inside.

cpUjCaxrct0mKUO3LCSzjA.text: When it was suggested we head to a Spanish bar/tapas place in Kings Cross, I wasn't filled with much hope. I wash half expecting a dingy La Tasca rip-off. The Kings Cross area isn't famed for its bar and restaurant options.But how wrong was I. If I wasn't led here, I might have struggled to find it, but I'm glad I did. Stripped flooring, lots of seating and some innovative décor and artwork - and of course the Iberian tilt to their drinks selection. Colour me impressed. The food is, if you're after bar snacks and light meals, realty really good. We sampled the mixed platter with some extra chorizo. Highly recommended.Not sure I'd trek here especially, but next time I find myself in the area in need of a bar, this will be where I come.

HHA-kUOsie_6Ikn_XFZcxg.text: Simple Spanish classics done well and served quickly. I was there for the lunch menu today and for £9.95 you can have two dishes and the portions sizes are just right for the time of day.They have Estrella on tap, a range of wines and ample outdoor seating in their courtyard area.I think to fully appreciate the menu you'll need to visit in the evening but you can't baulk at a nice meal for a nice price, especially in an area usually synonymous with kebabs and fried chicken.

Rhw2WCLhd3SOX3UCx-BFkg.text: This place SHOULD be a little gem in Kings Cross, tucked away out of sight to keep the tourists away, and reasonably priced with good food and a decent outdoor couryard. What is not to love? The barstaff, that is what! Was absolutely flabbergasted the last time I went here. The barmaid didn't even give me a chance to open my mouth before she was rolling her eyes and shrugging her shoulders at me. It was like I was he ex husband of 20 years who'd come to ask her to clean his shoes after cheating on her, taking all their money and having ten kids with a Russian supermodel. Seriously! She didn't even give me a chance to do anything wrong! She treated all my friends the same, and so we thought maybe she didn't like other women? But then she treated male customers the same! I later saw her laughing and chatting with a workmate, so I can only assume she HATES CUSTOMERS! I hope the management sort this problem out, the staff seem kind of tired and unhappy and like they hate life, which the customers do their best to ignore. Still, the food IS good, and the breakfast is cheap and amazing!

tp7hRT9W04QQG5QVOj2nvA.text: Hands down the best meal I have had in London so far.  In a city full of so-so tapas, I have finally found a place that rivals my favourite restaurant in Chicago with service to match to boot.I have been here quite a few times for drinks.  The wine menu is extensive and the bar area is usually hopping.  We recently tried for dinner and I know it will be a place I frequently return with friends and family.  The menu is quite extensive and much more sophisticated and adventurous than other so called "tapas" places here in London (I'm looking at you La Tasca).I highly recommend the lamp cutlets, the spinach croquettes, the goat cheese and pepper bread and garlic tiger prawns!!  Add a pitcher or two of their potent sangria and a bowl of their complementary olives and get ready for one of you the best meals in London!

ygQwVTKrFxSIjIOKicXXFw.text: Can't seem to spend a weekend in London without coming here at some point.Happened upon Camino when I came down for an Arsenal match. Glad I did as I'm sure, for the fly-by visitor, this might be a venue easily missed, located quite deep off Caledonian Road, down in Varnishers Yard (which, in itself, is a fantastic little find, with the likes of Bar Pepito across the way.). But given it's proximity to Kings Cross station, no tourist should pass up either a bite to eat or a few social drinks here.My first couple of visits have primarily consisted of the latter. The vibe in Camino is very after-office-crowd-meets-bohemian-student; laid back tunes from the DJ coupled with the stylish warehouse-brick interior, laden with funky memorabilia offer a relaxing, social atmosphere. And for those who are not native to London, this is an excellent venue to quash those inevitable "inhospitable" labels.On my last visit to Camino I sampled a quick lunch of Carrillera: pan-fried beef cheek with Malaga Virgen wine sauce and baby onions. With a little help from some salt, this dish was just what I needed after a long morning of flights and trains. And at £5.95, also good value. The restaurant is Spanish so the menu is full of similar dishes, many of which I'd never heard of but look forward to sampling on future visits.Staff are almost a little too cool for school. I say almost because, although they exude the moody Spanish look necessary for the role, they are more attentive to staff than a certain number of pretentious Edinburgh cocktail bars who employ mixologists that think they're B-list celebs and don't have to pay you, the paying customer, very much attention...!For me this is the jewel in the Varnisher's Yard crown that makes Kings Cross an excellent pre-lash destination.

3JIh1ZM0aOOwfMfhS3GwKg.text: The last time I had been there was to get a beer with a bunch of friends in the evening and all I remember was being jostled and shoved aside by patrons and waiters. I didn't really bother rating it then. Went back there again for Sunday brunch, reluctantly and not given a choice, and loved it! Not sure why I'm giving it three stars (I'm a tough marker), but i think I was expecting a lot less given it's location. I mean, can you blame me?We were 5 adults and a 3 mo old. There were two other occupied tables and the place was eerily quiet for being next to Kings Cross. My friend who was visiting from New York said that "churros" taste like french fries. OK, so he had never had churros, but why would say that? I'm going to count that as a negative from a patron.  The food was all good, but no points for creativity on the mixed and vegetarian platters (maybe I need to go back and try some of the real food, since we couldn't order many because there were two vegetarians on the table). Service was OK. It's London, and on top of that, Kings Cross. Don't expect a red carpet.Overall, good pick if you HAVE to dine at Kings Cross.

v1s0L0-AIpYvB8o2XoP6YQ.text: Nice setting in a hidden alley in kings cross. You an watch your food as it is prepared. The food it self is average/below average and expensive.

DV1cl_lTFwCXUWb-h9_gZQ.text: I came here to meet a friend for brunch after 20 days of traveling to Spain, Greece, Turkey, and Egypt. Camino was the perfect place to catch up and enjoy a light and delicious meal. First, the environment of the restaurant was great. The windows on the roof lets in a lot of light and transforms the gloomy King's Cross area into a fresh and clean space. Also, the service was friendly and relatively quick. For our meal, we ordered chorizo, fried eggs over potato and a large bruschette with roasted red peppers and eggplant. The chorizo was surprisingly tasty and authentic, especially since I had just returned from Spain. The two other dishes were cooked along the same vein, with bright and fresh flavors. Overall, I loved that the meal was hearty but didn't weight me down for the rest of the day.

bSxDRrXUXmXt10jx7upHwA.text: Went for drinks on a Saturday night. Had pan con tomate and it was the real deal, ditto the gin and tonic from the cocktail menu - 3-4 shots served in a huge wine glass - and the sangria. The decor wasn't particularly Spanish, more sort of Spanish memorabilia, but the food and drinks made up for that. Many vegetarian tapas but only a couple of vegan ones.

S3vXVsOS6d4R--UdXgmfAA.text: We were happy to be able to get a table at 9:15 on a Saturday night and the food was really good.  Great fresh bread, good croquetas and jamones and I loved the asparagus.  We really enjoyed our tapas.I didn't get the full lay of the land as we were on the restaurant side--looks like there is a big bar scene which was rockin' with Latin American music and they now have a sherry bar too.

zN4KBAeuA6Gjdz2BJgL4og.text: Camino was recommended to me as a lunch option. I was impressed with the online booking service which was followed up with a phone confirmation on the day. Not so impressed that the invite your guest online obviously didn't work (not sure if this is just a spam filter option).Even though I know Kings Cross fairly well, I am not familiar with the names of all the new developments. Regents Quarter means nothing to me and Varnishers Yard is not much of a help either. Why not admit it's on the corner of Caledonian and Pentonville? Having eventually found the place, the meal itself was lovely; the restaurant area is nice an airy with different sized sky lights. Not many tables were taking with most people congregating in the bar area on a Friday afternoon.The menu had a genuine Spanish feel to it and next time I will definitely try some of the tapas. Our chicken and scallop main courses were beautifully presented and tasty.Unfortunately, it all ended with a bit of a disappointment again as we were completely ignored by staff when it was time to pay up and leave. By that point only one other table was still occupied and staff milled about pointlessly. A bit more attention would have been welcome.

tVZj366TNpLO27PRXQS3ag.text: It ain't easy to find, and it's seen better days, but Camino can still deliver good times.I've never drunk beer here (with all the lovely wines on offer, why would you?) but can report a great selection of wines, and they've never disappointed.The food isn't quite as good as the wine selection. It's pretty standard tapas fare, for the most part. Good luck getting into the restaurant without a booking. You can still sample their tapas if you get a table...again, on a busy night, good luck.This isn't my Kings Cross watering-hole of choice anymore as it's too crowded and noisy (decent DJs, but you won't be able to hear anyone around you) for my taste. If you want a decent glass of wine and a lively setting, it's worth checking out.

lNlPeyMSmpVwrBmiX-a_uw.text: Saw the following advert for Camino in Kings Cross: "Sun Bailante Dj's will bring tropical fire to Camino's with a Special mix of the best Brazil and Colombian ground-shakers." .... well the DJ was fantastic no doubt BUT I can't say anything else positive about this place. The atmosphere was so dull. Walking in we were greeted by an indifferent woman who was seating people for meals, and when we asked about the Baile Funk night she had no idea what we were talking about - she eventually pointed us vaguely to the bar area past the restaurant. No problem I thought now it's about to get interesting... I was really looking forward to this! oh dear.... It was like walking into any bland old pub in the banking district, not a hint of the latin heat that the flyer implied/promised. Very disappointing. The dance floor area (not a designated area) was sort of near the DJ and if you were thinking about having a boogie you were constantly bumped into by the very harrassed looking staff who had to walk across the dance floor area to get the glasses back to the bar. They just have not thought this through, the layout the feel - and considering this is run by the same guys who run the VERY excellent Big Chill House just a few yards up the road I was mighty disappointed and thought it was a huge let down. Can't say i'll be back again though I loved the music (the 1 star is for the DJ!) - what's the point of good music when you can't enjoy it and have a good old baile/ dance without looking around wondering if you hadn't been better off listening to your iPod in your front room with your mates!!

rx4cXk-qKazFS3vunZ_TOg.text: I had lunch here today with a client. First the location: it's sort of inside a courtyard in a complex of renovated warehouses. It's quite hard to find from the outside but it's only a few minutes from Kings Cross station and it's quite a trendy media-ish sort of area near there. Wolff Olins is just up the road, for example. The place is in two barely-connected parts. One is a bar and it is obviously pretty lively in the evening. There's a DJ booth and a big, long bar. The other area is more restaurant-y and, at lunchtime anyway, quiet. There's a pleasant outdoor courtyard in the summer.The food was good. We had a set menu that wasn't tapas but Spanish food. In my case, a lovely vegetable soup and a potato/artichoke salad thing then an almond tart and coffee. The whole thing, including water, two coffees and two set three-course meals was around £45 which isn't bad. The service was quick but the place was fairly quiet. I've been here before and found the tapas a bit hit and miss. Sometimes very tasty and generous. Othertimes, tepid and meanly portioned. The coffees were particularly good.

O5fWeSHBnSEXb94NC0Y6FQ.text: Now anyone who dines with me will know that as soon, and I mean as soon as your food arrives my fork/spoon/chopsticks/shovel will be in it before you even have a chance to dig in yourself. Because of this I a.) have very select friends I eat with and b.)love sharing food places like Tapas joints. What's yours in mine and what's mine is my own if you didn't know already!Now Camino is a little bit of a glorified La Tasca but the food is less greasy, the service friendlier, if a little too friendly and their sangria strong. All winning points I'll add! So yes the waitress was slow and they did sit our large group on 2 tables because apparently if you have more than 8 at a table you MUST have their set menu which will cost your granny. Actually, at this point in the review I removed a star from 4 to 5. My granny is worth a star!So yes, come here eat, share food, get the prawns they are lovely, as is the squid ink risotto, and you are sure to have a lovely evening out.

Uit4giVq4Y1q1vhCG-9lYQ.text: I went here for the first time yesterday after reading a review of the place in a February edition of London Lite recommending the breakfast and coffee. Set back away from the hustle and bustle of King's Cross, this place is enormous and perfect for after work drinks. The venue itself is divided into a restaurant and several more casual areas with tables, stools, bars and sofas, as well as free wifi. House red decent, as was the draught Cruzcampo beer, served in frozen glasses. Not bad for February (when it was snowing), even better in July where they appear to have the use of a decent-sized open air area. Also of interest was the 'Cafe Bonbom, an expresso coffee with very sweet and syrupy cream - I like sweet things, so this was perfect for me, although perhaps not to everyone's taste. Before leaving, I also sampled some of the tapas: the acorn fed, Iberian ham was excellent (and described in the menu as the world's best), the spinach croquettes were very good and an onion-style bruchetta was delicious, but probably not a good idea before a first date! Before I left at about 6pm, the place had really livened up and was heaving with after work types. I can see why as it had a really nice atmosphere and ticked lots of boxes: food, tick. Drinks, tick. Atmosphere, tick. According to several sources, the breakfasts (which go on until 4pm at the weekend) are an absolute must, so that'll be next on my list. Come here and I'm sure you won't be disappointed.

photos.caption: Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom

Cw8kbTpYr2H68r1TvAXxNg.text: Great tapas and breakfasts.Caminos is packed so if you want to book for dinner, do it in advanced or else you and your party will have to wait over an hour. I recommend any of the assorted platters. We ordered the one with bruschetta, calamari, chorizo, shrimp, deep fried cheese in batter (a lot lighter version than the one they serve in the U.S.) and roasted chilis. My favorite tapas is the roasted chilis (so simple, yet so good). The potatoes with a red bell pepper sauce was delicious, but wasn't included with the platter).  I wasn't impressed with the lamb skewers, even though I am a big fan of lamb.Will upload a photo.

photos.caption: Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom. Tapas... loved the roasted green chilis there.

H3SZFGbcg3-GyX4brwV8oQ.text: I have to agree with Linzi on the gastro-pub thing.  Large, airy restaurant and bar areas, but I think tapas suits a more intimate, grungy setting.I would have liked to see more fresh dips, garnishes and sauces to cut through the richness of the fried food.Scrumptious sangria!

8do5zTzWmulht-6oImdGlA.text: Camino is a fantastic place if you are in the area (aka travelling from St.Pancras) and need a place for a quick few platters -tapas- and drinks. The staff was very nice and helpful and the food we ordered, including mixed grill plate, patatas bravas and avocado salad, was tasty.

g6YgL8r9I3j7Ze81v812Tg.text: The bar was open when we passed this place on a bank holiday monday however we decided to come back another day when the restaurant was open. Good decision.Camino is a cool spanish tapas style food which makes a great stop for something light but filling. A great place to eat with some friends in a relaxed laid back but still classy environment.The cheese/figs wrapped in parma ham is a must-try. Everything else was good, well cooked but for asian tastebuds can be a little bland. This is fine for those watching their blood pressure I guess, but be ready to add salt particularly to the tuber/marrow family of foods. The quality of everything was cooked fantastically. Potatoes were sautéed to perfection. The squid sauce was lacking but no complaints about the creaminess of the squid (yep a feature I would never have associated with that piece of seafood). Ordering a few dishes and sharing is the winningest way to eat here.Price was, for the quantities and simplicity of what you're getting a little pricey. Expect £20-30 per head. However in the context of the great environment, superb service and general satisfaction of each dish, this place is a great introduction to Spanish style tapas and there are plenty more interesting things I'd like to try on the menu.Make sure to pick up the membership card at the end of your meal. Points will rack up pretty slowly, but registering it online will give you instantly 500 points or £5 off your next meal here.

photos.caption: Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom. Ensalada de higos and Huevo con calabaza

f7xf40T1hscK-pMp1rVbww.text: I brought my parents here and it exceeded my expectations. I felt like being back in Spain... the tapas were that good. It's quite expensive but the quality of each dish was incredible... they have a good range of choices and it was difficult to stop ordering. Do try everything! The waiters are really nice but the service can be slow so don't eat too quickly, since the portions are small. The place can be hard to find because it's hidden inside a small alleyway so do check google street view first.

photos.caption: Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom

zU6p0woLQbJqcxaDmG2FGg.text: The place is ok, the staff is very nice and helpful and the food is tasty. But... I think it is a little bit overpriced. We all know that a tapa size it is not massive, but I found them very small here. Try the croquetas, they taste like croquetas at home (=Spain) and the boquerones (if you like anchovies), and for a lovely treat... tarta de Santiago! (an almond tart they bring from Galicia, Spain). And again, at least the day I had lunch there, the waiters were so nice!

gzA3GBJNe6lu78ut036jLw.text: I cannot boast enough about how excellent this restaurant is! First time in London and will DEF be going back. My friends and I ordered the Mixed Grill plate which was made to perfection! We thought it wouldn't be enough but for 3 it was plenty! But the best part of this place has to be the patatas bravas! They were so good, we had to order 2 (don't judge me!) The staff was veryyyyy nice and kept pouring us water and checking in on us. We ordered a pomegranite/champagne type drink....just perfect for brunch!

J2R_ntTlL6KYFcRBe1x2BA.text: Overpriced, under seasoned and underwhelming. While the atmosphere of this place is relatively nice, not one bit of the tapas or drinks that I ordered were good.Bland bloody mary with barely any alcohol in it, overly dressed salad, and freezer-flavor reminiscent garlic bread. This meal was incredibly unmemorable, the only memorable part was when the bill came and it said 15 quid for what I ordered.

pR4rEqDAgKgx2M4Ni7EgNw.text: I've been coming to Camino since a weekend trip in 2009, when I was working for 10 weeks in Altrincham. I took the Virgin Train down from Manchester, and stayed at a hotel near King's Cross. A quick search for tapas places within walking distance came back with Camino, and now I try to include it into every trip to London or Slough I make.Even though I've never had an issue walking up and getting a table at Camino, I decided to use their online booking. What with all that's going on in London this summer, I figured it was the safe bet. The place was busy, but there were a few seats at the bar, so I would've been OK as a single. The number of tables each server worked was a bit high, but the attitude of staff was good even if response time was a bit slow.Wine flights! While perusing the menu, I really had no idea what I wanted to eat, so I went back to the wines first. When I saw the wine flight listings, I thought that would be a good change of pace from getting just a bottle of something cheap (since I don't usually buy a good wine all for myself). I decided to start with the dry sherry flight. Clockwise from front, Amontillado, Manzanilla, and Fino.I paired the sherry flight with the "Tabla de Quesos," which was three lovely cheeses and various sweets, nuts, and crackers. I started with the Amontillado first, going to the Fino, then the Manzanilla last, comparing the wines with the cheeses. More research is required here; all the combinations were enjoyable. Because of the big shift between a sherry flight and a red wine flight, I decided to have a glass of Camino's sangria while waiting for the second set of tapas to come out. So, this meal became more of a starter-and-main sort of affair than just a bunch of small platesFor the "main" -- Conchinillo con Morcilla - Roasted suckling pig from Aragon with Burgos morcilla, apple puree and thyme. Morcilla is Spanish blood sausage...boudin to you New Orleanians, "black pudding" to you lot in the UK. The morcilla is underneath a generous slice of roast pork, which had a great skin and a lovely sauce. The applesauce was such a great addition, as well. Add some great brown bread to these two, and it was a real winner. I added Grilled asparagus with romesco sauce as a veggie, and were they ever wonderful!To accompany the pork and asparagus--Red Wine Flight! Three Tempranillos, from Castilla y Leon, Rioja and Ribera. Lovely wines, all.Dessert: Postel de Chocolate, a flourless individual cake with a "molten" chocolate pudding filling, ginger ice cream, and a bit of raspberry sauce. The wine is a all de Xaló Mistela, a Spanish fortified wine.Service: this trip, a bit slow. Not sure if that's because of the crowd that evening or if there was a problem in the kitchen, but things didn't come out as fast as they have in the past. Gave me time to let all this food settle, but still, problematic.Overall, however, this meal was a winner, continuing my appreciation for Camino.

photos.caption: Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom. Amontillado!

eP-JGPK0oQyH-i7YPFBtQg.text: The jury's out on this one. The tapas was so so, nothing special. Ingredients likewise pretty mediocre. Didn't look at the wine list, but the £30 Garnacha could've been quite a bit better for the price point. Sat at the bar to eat. Prob one of best places (for a duo!) in restaurant, apart from if you manage to snag a table by the windows facing the inner courtyard. Great thing about being at the bar is the ultra-quick service, being able to see through to the other side, and being able to have an a lot more private conversation.So what's good about this place? The bar set-up was comfortable (nothing like 10 Greek Street's butt-sleep-inducing, elbow-your-neighbours bar area) and the service pretty good. Not sure I'll be running back. The food is not a pull at all. This is more like a back-up option place, if you are hungry and your options are few. Turns out the jury's back in!

mHFJTpOqjvc2fqu38Lg3eQ.text: Was here back in 2013. Best Tapas I've ever had, from an American perspective, growing up eating Latin American/Caribbean food from Miami. I recommend this place to everyone I know who travels to London. The DJ was fantastic, and the ambience was very festive. The jamon iberico was delicious!!!

RDAY3752r6OpW3_TxvZHYg.text: If you just got off the Eurostar and are craving a good lunch or dinner, Camino is the perfect place to enjoy delicious tapas ! The place is spacious and the waiters are friendly. It is best not to be in a rush though. The menu offers a large selection of tapas. We had the spicy patatas bravas, chorizo, tortilla, Iberic ham, arroz negro - rice with squid ink - and empanadillas filled with spinach and goat cheese. Everything was delicious and you can order as many different tapas as you like. It might be worth coming back at night to have a few drinks and enjoy the live music.

CShqtHeY4gIKGIZIZhTO_g.text: So the lady at the reception desk had no clue what she was talking about in terms of available seating, she told me the wait would be 30-45 min. I took it upon myself to point out that there was seats available so I was able to get a seat in 2mins. Stress.The waiter completely made up for everything, he was helpful, passionate, enthusiastic and very friendly! I had a great food experience here and hands down i have had the best tapas here. Very surprisingly filling. And quick service. Great wine. Great atmosphere. Pricey, but worth it

photos.caption: Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom. Highly recommend

36HHHGqfpaReTATnPKFYtQ.text: The best tapas restaurant I've ever been to! Vegetarian friendly , great service , and so delicious !! I'm recommending it to all my friends and clients who visit London. Thanks again!

sdmkGwYQqfsnJt9LdPpj8g.text: Good food and wine after a day out in London. Wine: Rioja Tinto Organic, Artisia 2012 was very good. Excellent service too.

pZsdOV6Xw5rE7rNZKVn0Qw.text: Well peeps, do I have to tell you that they have the meat on this island? If so, then go for the Solomiller 5oz fillet steak with cabrales cream sauce and roasted winter vegetables. The meat is from Spain, more precise Basque county. It is called Sagatoki. As a starter I had the bread with tomatoes... Sounds simple, but isn't.I ordered the meat medium well, the you can skip the sauce, because the meat overwhelmes (did i just make up this word?)everything!It s grilled on (of course) a special Spanish grill. And it's well worth the investment. The atmosphere was great, the bartender and the waiters were very nice (like in Spain). So an overall 5* experience. Hat a treat in the middle of all the chain restaurants. Every time again

HHl-nif_zbdxbOXEwpNV1g.text: Not as expensive as I thought it would be from looking at the menu. Food for two people was under £40.The bartenders actually look for people trying to get their attention, a very welcome change from most places. The best dish was the TXIGORKI (Basque bread with goat cheese), followed by the VALDEÓN if you like a not-overpowering blue cheese. The Iberico ham was a little fatty, but a flavourful and hefty portion. Garlic prawns are a tapas staple -- these were pretty good, but the sauce they used was cloudy and heavier than I've had at other places.

2NykpQuCUG9vLgHC9uhsjw.text: Food: Had dinner, spanish tapas style. Menu had great range of choice to please all palettes and nice veggie options too, nice portion sizes, (recommend the lemon olive starter and pork stuffed with figs and cheese a that was a nice surprise) and desserts and cocktails looked interesting but I didn't have any.Service: Great, friendly staff. Very nice and attentive without you realising they were there. Even tap water was topped up regularly! Look/atmosphere: Restaurant exterior is tucked away neatly and very quiet clean alley, you don't realise you are in the centre of kings cross. Interior is pleasing to the eye, clean, modern wood design and tables spaced apart nicely. Music is different on each night - sometimes live or dj but might be a little loud for some (I didnt mind though) Table for 2 is smallish if you wanted lots of tapas buts not hard to eat quicker as food tasted great!Price: Great quality food and totally value for money, about £20 per head. If you become a regular there is a loyalty card scheme and you can get points and free bits now and again. Overall: 5/5 - I had a great experience there. Nice mid range fancy-ish drinks and tapas for an evening with friends, good portion sizes and nice selection at a great price. Planning to go back again soon ; )

xP7IEsIo11J0BgJHJ3h6gg.text: Pros: the service was very good.  The food was also very good.  For this neighborhood the prices were very reasonable, good value for money. Cons: the room is quite lively, and it can be down right noisy. Also, if you use plastic and are from the US, their cc service automatically converts the bill from £ to $ at a VERY unfavorable rate (much worse than my bank), so beware.  The next time I go there I will bring cash.

IYj5VLb5gKa4jj4Hrfj02Q.text: Located near my office, this is a great spot for client lunches and dinners in Kings Cross, located in a lovely little courtyard away from tourists and those in and out of the station. Good priced tapas, beautiful meat platters and the piedmont peppers are a must with a glass of wine as an aperitif.

c8r0xkZ9KoQ0L19D9mqp_Q.text: Really cool space. They have an unassuming entry that leads into a separate bar and a dining area. I sat in the bar, which is adjacent to a court yard, which is a nice little perk. I went there on a first date and it was perfect- just loud enough so you'd have to sit close, but just busy enough to be distracted if your partner isn't entertaining.In terms of food, it was just okay. Nothing wowed me. As for drinks- really interesting menu, and very tasty (hence the 4 stars)!I would totally go back and recommend it to others.

cpYwc04R20e2RIomFM-I8g.text: I have really enjoyed the last evening at this tapas bar. There's lots of space and different rooms where you can have either a full dinner or where you can just sit down in cosy leather armchairs, in order to chat with your friends, eat some tapas and enjoy the yummy homemade sangria.The staff is friendly, the food is delicious and  as I said  the sangria is yummy and refreshing. You can sit outside  there's a a courtyard which looks quity nice, as well. To sum up, I can happily recommend this place to you!

N3CM0rAYY48PUuOOtvrLMg.text: Definitely on my list of my favorite places in London! Went here with my family for dinner as we're big fans of traditional Spanish tapas. It seemed pretty busy when we went, but it was easy to grab a table for four without a reservation. We got a pretty nice spread: tomato bread (simple, but tasty!), embutidos, jamon, arroz negro (probably one of my favorite things to eat there), the rib eye, and the Iberico meatballs. Everything was very tasty - I don't have a bad thing to say about anything we had.This place is great for groups and overall a very friendly atmosphere. Our server had quite the load as they seemed a little short-staffed when we went, but he was very attentive to our needs and made some excellent recommendations. Will definitely be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom. Hello, meat perfection.
Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom. Jamon
Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom. Embutidos

amYY89pMw_SsqDR9kJSq4A.text: Been coming here for 2+ years. Always bring my friends here because it's a great little spot hidden away from the noise of King's X. Very let down tonight. Say they close at midnight but decided to close early at 10. Let us order food 10 mins till 10...never mentioned they were closing early. Still brought our food in a rush, potato's bravas a bit undercooked because of the hurry. Went to go get another drink said the bar was closed and never did last call. Said they rang the bell for last call- not one of us out of 3 of us ever heard a bell. Normally when you ring a bell you yell 'last call.' Yet 2 minutes later they let 2 people order beer and said that the one guy worked there. Very rude and disrespectful after they made a huge deal to not serve us. If you're going to serve your employees free beer once you "shut it down" how bout you wait until your customers leave the establishment...and side note...please don't rush us out of there and spray cleaning agent on the tables next to us as we are still eating dinner. Thanks

pi-mdFxvGIYmn7ZGledXcg.text: Camino is a traditional Spanish restaurant and bar.We ordered nine tapas. The food is quite good. Nice place for chat with friends and groups.

photos.caption: Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom

FTjr_wJJUrJwKoe4tU51ug.text: Came here for a work lunch, and thank goodness, because tapas can really drain your wallet. It was not too crowded for a Friday - we probably didn't need our reservation.I was pleasantly surprised by all the vegetarian options. Loved the cheese platter, but it's quite small. We definitely needed 2 for a group of 6. The arzua ulloa was really good, although not what I expected - I was imagining stringy cheese like in a mozzarella stick, but it's an airy, crisp experience. At the waitress' suggestion, we got the spinach salad - I think you can skip it.Overall I enjoyed it, but the price was a little high for many return visits.

qbmSmzqiXPAwMLeOu2XivA.text: Yes its somewhat of a chain but it s not your average tapas chain. its a good mix between classics and more creative dishes or products.Its the first time I tasted cured beef and it was absolutely delicious.The arroz negro was perfectly cooked and the creamy aioli really complemented the squid ink.The morcilla was classic but good, same for the pan con tomate (though better than at most generic tapas places),But the star of the night was the special: Sandria with cured cod. Its made with watermelon marinated in sangria and served with slices of safran cured cod. An absolute delight and a must order if available. I was impressed and would comeback!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom

b-p4HbDRR2MgfX7el0zc2g.text: I've worked in this area for years but never made it to Camino, but today I was walking by and noticed the Express Lunch - 2 tapas for £6.95 so decided to give it a go.It's tucked away in a quiet little courtyard but there's a sign on the main road to help you find your way. Inside, the restaurant is really big - and today at 1pm, pretty empty and also really quite warm (much warmer than outside).The express menu has 8-10 things on it. I went for the ham & cheese croquetas and the huevos rotos (I wanted patatas bravas but they weren't on the express menu - odd, as I'd think it'd cost them less and be quicker than frying eggs!) Complimentary olives are brought - nice but not great.Even though I only had the 2 things, they came out at different times, with the croquettas appearing first. You get 4 and they're the size of a ping pong ball. I enjoyed them  - I found them  pretty much the same as the ones from Brindisa. Then the huevos rotos came out. Having learned how to make this dish from Omar Allibhoy directly in a private lesson (I'm not above name-dropping), I knew what to expect - broken eggs (hence the same) mixed with sauteed potatoes with maybe some onions and peppers (I didn't want to spend the extra £2 for chorizo). Oddly though it was 2 fried eggs on top of some fried potato rounds - a huge portion, but odd. The potatoes were nice but the eggs were overcooked, and didn't ooze at all (the waiter offered to 'cut the huevos' for me. As I've been using cutlery for over 30 years, I declined and managed it all on my own). The bill was actually nearly £12, because of the Coke and the service charge. Too much for lunch that's 2 tapas plates, to be honest. They use the Zapper app and if you've never used it, download it and when the bill comes, open it and scan the QR code. You can pay via your phone and get £5 off your first time.

photos.caption: Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom. Croquettes and olives
Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom. Huevos rotos

xbsItPGHGORHgc1135BjrQ.text: Everything was delicious and accompanied by an excellent wine.  I had the pork loin and my wife the lamb chop, both seasoned in uniquely Hibernian spices and worth trying.  As expected the dishes are small, but a selection of three or so will satisfy most diners and leave you with a tab of about 20 £.  We added appetizers, cinnamon ice cream,  a 40£ wine, and two glasses of Sangria to celebrate the last meal of an extended trip, and our bill for three adults was 150£.

1VvQZI600pGThSb531GdZg.text: A small chain serving Spanish tapas for breakfast, lunch and dinner. It's quite a reliable chain, no fancy affair but just expect to find the classic dishes and usually done quite well. I do enjoy the restaurant hidden in a quiet courtyard away from the hustle and bustle of King's Cross. Yet is makes it very convenient to get to. The restaurant is very spacious, made to look modern and clean. The large windows also allows a lot of natural light in. It was a really comfortable place to settle in to. Bacon rollStarting with a lovely bacon roll with coffee for just £4.00. A lovely soft white toasted bun filled with crispy bacon, rocket, tomatoes and added cheese. The flavours were all very balanced with the rocket adding a nice earthiness to the cured bacon and tomato providing moisture. Highly recommend adding the lovely stretchy cheese to add depth, also to keep in the heat and binding all the ingredients together.Tortilla de patata This was a lot better than it looks. The potato slices were beautifully soft and tender, rich in yolk making it nice and creamy in between and seasoned beautifully. Full Spanish breakfast Genuiely suprised at how delicious this was and all very well composed. The morcilla was lovely, fluffy and bringing in a lot of flavours. Chorizo was one of the softest ones I've had and a very welcomed new texture to enjoy pairing well with the other soft textures in the dish. The flavours were nice bringing in sweet and spicy notes. Bacon was crispy and greaseless. Roasted piquilla peppers were cut thin, melting soft and really juicy and sweet. Refreshing! Potatoes were reasonable in taste, crispy and fluffy inside and a fried egg and bread is always welcomed on any dish for me.Omelette of Serrano ham and arzúa cheese This was nice and simple. Cooked firm yet still remaining its moisture and bounce. Lovely chunks of ham to give flavour and enough cheese for that creamy comforting feel. Served with toasted breadChurros + chocolate Pretty good if you ask me. It was nice and crispy yet doughy as you chew on it. They were very satisfying just on its own, sprinkled with powered sugar and of course if you like a little more indulgence than you can always dip it in the rich thick milky chocolate dip. Delicious.For a chain that expanded a lot since the last few years I am very impressed at how the quality of food is still consistently good. Pricing is also very reasonable and affordable, especially for breakfast. Much more variety than the usual cafes and breakfast places in King's Cross which makes it refreshing and exciting. Staff were friendly and smiley which contributed a lot to the relaxing airy atmosphere. We could have stayed here all day but sadly we had other plans.

photos.caption: Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom. Exterior
Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom. Churros
Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom. Omelette of Serrano ham and arzua cheese

NkFgBSTXNGn76PRjx7y_iA.text: The place is OK in general. Being Spanish, I think I know a thing or two about tapas and I have to say that the ones in Camino are so so... Patatas Bravas were ok, but the Croquetas were a big no (frozen ones from Iceland maybe?). Drinks are expensive, but they have Mahou beer, so they can be forgiven...Staff was friendly and the bar is nice. I loved all the posters around the place! Good place to meet with friends for a couple of drinks after work as it is very big and there is lot of space to sit and chat! Also table football!

photos.caption: Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom

q5wxggRG_yhVHxhPCxWJyA.text: The bar area was huge and lacked atmosphere, so we chose the area near the entrance.  The food was a hit & miss.Bunuelos de Bacalao was bland and the texture was mushy.Pulpo con Cachelos was simply excellent.  It was tender, flavourful and very tasty.Gambas al Ajillo (we ordered it without garlic) was just an ordinary prawn cooked in lots of butter.  I was expecting the grilled ones for better flavour.Chipirones was tender and tasty.Pinchito de Pollo was very, very salty.Jamon Teruel & Iberico Cebo was lovely.Burger Iberico was very meaty.It's better to avoid dessert.  Both Tarta Santiago and Tocino di Cielo didn't deliver. Jorge Ordonez Victoria dessert wine was aromatic. The waitress we had was lovely and helpful.  Food wise, I prefer Polpo.

yEkIo3XSKi6iowDQza72jw.text: No stars for caminos as I'm forced to put 1 !!!!!!!!!!!!!This place was so bad I don't know where to start.Was here for my nieces birthday and she had booked a table for 20 people (good buisness ay)Apparently there was supposed to be a set menu of tapas at £28 per head. you would expect to eat RIGHT.There was bread not a lot ,but BREAD and some chorizo plates!! about 6 plates with four bits on each plate between 20 AND defo the frozen kind.Then came the  four plates of olives woop woop Followed by some pork that wasn't cooked properly and enough to feed a cat ( I'm not joking))6 plates to share once again.Then desert :)Almond tart with a squirt anchors cream on the top .So embarrassing!Who does this with Spanish food .Who's idea of tapas is this .He cannot be Spanish that's for sure.IM NOT FINISHEDMy niece who did call the manager to have a word replies with we were busy in the kitchen today and forgot we were coming lolMy niece booked ahead 2 weeks and as for busy in the kitchen ,there wasn't any FOOD LOL busy with what . He then gave her £5 discount yes people £5.Not to mention all the homeless people banging on the Windows watching us eat and giving us the bird . I felt like I was in a zombie movie .Stay well clear to avoid disappointment.

Ax98zl-Qza3KfhNWeaG_tQ.text: The-food-is-great ! I came across Camino with some friends visiting us in London because they were staying nearby and I can't wait to go back to try more dishes. We all had the lunch tapas formula. It was cheap and portions were satisfying. And most importantly, it tasted very good. I don't know about the prices of the other dishes, but we were on the run and this formula was convenient both for price and efficiency. We were almost the only ones in the restaurant because we showed up at the end of the service. We were served fast as required and with pleasantness. The place looks nice, and I could spot their bar, in the next room. It is situated in a little cul-de-sac where you'll find other bars. I was told that at night it's like a big party, all the customers from Camino's bar and the other 2 mingling in the hidden patio.

Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom

yAaV3OSqcg6k47l_y36QNw.text: I wish this review could be more positive. I visited Camino on a Sunday night. Good vibe in the restaurant and not overly busy. Service was a bit discombobulated however and dishes took long(er) to arrive. I also thought the dishes themselves were very basic and uninspiring. Real pity.

1gCNENZ5Cs1JUBVlAOCSvQ.text: So far so good!  Had the express lunch menu and excellent flavours.  Surprised this wasn't rated higher by the Yelp community. Nice casual ambience, rustic but elegant decor - dime patio space.  Nr St Pancras station!

photos.caption: Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom. Sausage potato and eggs
Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom. Crispy baby squid, potato with eggs, ham croquettes
Photo of Camino - London, United Kingdom. Express lunch menu for 6.95 any 2 dishes

ixk42w1KRCvimdtve4AgSA.text: I've been going to Camino for a number of years now and it's good both as a restaurant and as a bar. Most recently we were here for a drink and shared a bottle of wine, a very drinkable red at a good price, the place was busy but we managed to get a couch and catch up. The place is well designed so that the restaurant and bar remain separate from one another so that it doesn't become a conflict between those dining and those drinking. The bar extends quite far into the building so finding space isn't normally an issue, the outdoor area and the table football add the area. On the restaurant side, although maybe a little pricy, the tapas and larger courses are brilliant, share a platter as you won't be disappointed!

zUfopHY9Lib_Hv-3BcT6uA.text: The atmosphere was attractive and warm but I never got to try the restaurant. The hostess was intent on having me sit by the  server station or in a corner where I could not use my left arm. The restaurant was only 1/3 full at 10 pm but she wouldn't budge. If service and comfort is important id skip this place unless you come in nice even numbers. Look across the street on the corner there's a few gems there.

kYFHOz1NPCwAuLqyF1Wsmg.text: I've come here on a few occasions on a Friday night and have always, without fail, had a great time. You can book a table, but if you get there for 7:30ish, it's likely you'll get a table.Why does this place make me happy? It's a mixture of great music with occasional Latin tunes and old-school classics, a cool outdoor courtyard which is just as packed as inside and the party is going on both inside and out! What's also nice about this place is that it never feels too crowded and there's a cool mix of people here too. The tapas are good, but a tad overpriced for the portions you get. The final thing that makes me merry? Their sangria is DAMN GOOD ;)

hs4htIUfkGyb0aqXpZcbqA.text: Great tapas near King's cross: One of the best Spanish tapas restaurant in London! Good service and great food even if the atmosphere Iquitos odd.I will come back again

HKEjjT14oTXds162jguGwQ.text: Nice food. Friendly service. Odd table location choice.I met a friend here for lunch and had to follow my nose a bit - it is a little hidden away in a courtyard. My friend was already at the table, and out of a sea of many many empty tables, the host had placed us in between the only two occupied tables in the place. I found this a little odd, but didn't (unusually) make a fuss! I was facing the kitchen and it was quite interesting to see all the preparation and goings on there anyway. Plus the couple to the right of us were clearly having a very quiet row and that was quite entertaining! We ordered a few things to share, thinking that we would see how we went and then order some more. We actually didn't end up ordering any more as the plates are fairly generous portions and, well it was only lunchtime! We ordered a mixed cheese plate, ham croquettes, chorizo, a special salad with cheese and pears and patatas bravas. Everything was delicious - but the salad blew me away. I rather hogged that plate and bargained the chorizo and potatoes for it! It never really got very busy - so I'm not sure what the policy of cramming everyone into one corner was about, perhaps the waiter preferred not to walk so far...? It was a good overall experience though. I understand that Camino also has restaurants in Blackfriars and Monument, which I shall certainly be trying at some point soon.

VTsr5XKgyuRC_va3OibR4g.text: 20 minutes for a cold tortilla de patatas which was cold and flavourless: place was empty. Cafe con leche was lukewarm and tiny. Then they tried to charge 12% service for worst service I've had in London.Under no circumstances should you visit this faux-Spanish tacky place. Only nice thing about this place was the maitre dee's dmile.
